Author: jl777c#5810

Author: jl777c#5810

Author: zack#6467
Content:
creating a trustful tool on the blockchain is so easy.
I could create a blockchain where you email me your contracts, and then I make on-chain signatures to say the result of each contract.
If I called that a "smart contract blockchain to compete with ethereum", you can see how that would be a scam, right?
I could do this with bitcoin today, but we don't call bitcoin a "smart contract platform to compete with ethereum".

So why can't you see that building a centralized version of oracles on blockchains, and advertising them as an equivalent alternative to the trustless ones, is also a scam?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are using the definition of oracle to mean getting offchain data onchain

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are not claiming trustless oracles are magically created

Author: zack#6467
Content:
and I am using the definition of "smart contract" to mean that Bob runs your contract and signs the result to the blockchain.
This is the old joke of "Bobchain". 
A centralized blockchain where one guy signs over the results of every transaction sent to him.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
Bitcoin is can be used as a trusted smart contract platform, if we all trust Bob to run our smart contracts and keep track of the data.
But that doesn't make bitcoin a smart contract platform.

By default, all on-chain stuff is supposed to be trust free, and you need to clearly specify if you are doing something trusted on-chain. Because in general, people don't want to use trust on-chain.

Author: zack#6467
Content:
in Amoveo reporters are doing bets on a single bit of  data, whos value is ultimately determined by nakamoto consensus.
In Bitcoin Hivemind there is commit-reveal voting followed by rebalancing of votecoin ownership based upon how much you followed the median opinion.
